awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide an effective and low-cost means for inhibiting the growth of pathogenic or problematic bacteria in the environment. There is growing concern that the widespread use of antibiotics and biocides has promoted the evolution of resistant bacterial strains for which there exist few effective treatments. The proposed technology is being developed as a safer and more environmentally sustainable alternative to antibiotics and biocides, or may be used as part of a combination treatment to enhance their effects. Additionally, the proposed technology is selective, and can target specific bacteria within a population, thus preserving the function of beneficial species. Successful implementation of this project will lead to the development of a wide range of products useful for controlling bacteria in both built and natural environments. Specific applications are expected to include the control of agricultural pathogens, mitigation of petroleum reservoir souring, optimization of wastewater treatment processes, and microbiome engineering.

This I-Corps project is based on a novel technology platform for the isolation and application of extremely wide host-range (polyvalent) bacteriophages (viruses that only infect bacteria). The vast majority of bacteriophages reported in scientific studies and developed for commercial use have had a narrow host-range, likely due to the use of biased isolation techniques. In contrast, the proposed technology preferentially isolates only very wide host-range bacteriophages. Polyvalent bacteriophages have the potential to be significantly more effective than narrow host-range bacteriophages at controlling target bacteria in many natural and built environments, including biofilms. They have been shown to be 10- to 100-fold more effective at inhibiting the growth of their target bacteria, and have been successfully utilized to eliminate 99.99% of an antibiotic resistance gene from a wastewater sample. When used in combination with antibiotics or biocides, the technology is expected to work synergistically, enabling long-term and more complete control of problematic bacteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a commercialization plan and obtaining customer validation for a selective bacterial control technology based on wide host-range (polyvalent) bacteriophages. Bacteriophages (phages) are viruses that only infect bacteria, and they have been used for over 100 years as antimicrobials. Recent concern over antibiotic resistant bacteria has led to renewed interest in their use, and our lab has worked to develop them for various environmental applications. Our strategy has been to utilize polyvalent phages (versus narrow host-range phages) as their capacity to infect a variety of hosts within an environment can lead to greater efficacy and reduced costs for treatment. The main objective was to obtain training in research commercialization and then apply this knowledge while performing customer discovery to validate our business plan. Over the course of this project, we conducted 138 interviews with potential customers.

A major outcome of this project was a pivot in our initial commercialization strategy, which was targeting sulfate-reducing bacteria in oil and gas wells to reduce souring (product contamination by hydrogen sulfide gas). Souring is a major problem for the oil and gas industry, costing billions of dollars each year. However, after conducting a limited number of interviews and applying the lessons taught during the workshops, we determined that the agricultural industry would be a better initial target market. Antibiotics are commonly used in livestock production and account for approximately 80% of all antibiotic use. Thus, decreasing their use in animal agriculture might help slow the proliferation of antibiotic resistant bacteria. Initially we investigated interest in increasing animal growth rates by targeting specific bacteria that are associated with either growth or feed efficiency. However, during our interviews, we realized that in-feed antibiotics are primarily used in cattle feedlots to prevent liver abscesses. A single bacterial species, Fusobacterium necrophorum, is believed to be the causative agent, making this challenge a good fit for our technology. Subsequently, we received substantial interest in developing this idea, including offers to help with testing and animal studies in the future. We then determined we had a good product-market fit, and decided to move forward with this application by submitting an NSF Phase I SBIR proposal, which was successfully awarded in June 2018. Thus, the broader impact of this project is initiating development of a potential alternative to antibiotics and biocides used in animal feed, which will help mitigate the global health threat of multidrug-resistant bacteria.

Another outcome of this project, which occurred through continuing customer discovery, was the identification of a second target bacterial species. We discovered that there was significant interest in a method for selectively eliminating methanogenic microbes from cattle rumen. Such methanogens not only reduce animal feed efficiency, increasing producer feed costs, but produce methane, which is a potent greenhouse gas. Therefore reducing their abundance would provide both economic and environmental benefits. Based on this realization we were able to initiate a small study to test the feasibility of using our methods for isolating archael viruses that can target methanogens commonly found in cattle rumen.
